title: The ‘Fear Trade’ Is Getting Crowded. Going the Other Way Could Pay Off.
text:
The fourth quarter tends to be a good one for stocks, but not always. Last year was a big exception, and the hangover from that debacle is clearly still weighing on fund managers. In a year when the S&P 500 is already up more than 16%, many fund managers appear to be looking to lock in those gains rather than expose themselves to more risk.

Wells Fargo analyst Christopher Harvey argues that portfolio managers are “trading scared,” leading to a pileup in low-volatility stocks. The consensus among investors seems to be...
description: What Wells Fargo calls the “pain trade”—betting on a reflation in rates, stabilizing-to-improving growth, and a resolution to the U.S.-China trade war—is so out of favor, it could actually rise into year end.
